comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saltillo Date written on negative is 3/7/29. Bain may have used the photo later. NYT of May 24, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9500E3DF1F39E633A... says "EL PASO, May 23. -- Saltillo, the show city of the central part of Mexico, was found in ruins when the revolutionary forces entered it on Friday. " NYT of March 14,1929 does indicate that Saltillo was again in the news. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0B1FFF395A167A... says "General Cedillo, Federal general moving on Torreon, reports the capture of 4,000 rebels in retreat from Saltillo, the Associated Press says."

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: many pictures (mutual, bain news, etc) of different years and places show 3/7/29 [in example photo Call Nr 3033-12]

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Saltillo, capital of the Coahuila State, situated almost on the extreme south east of the state.
In this photo the camera is facing north-east (upper margin and right upper corner of the picture) 
To your left runs Lic. Benito Juárez Street; to your right, Emilio Castelar, both surround the cathedral, here seen by behind.  The first street back to the cathedral is General Nicolás Bravo, the second, General Victoriano Cepeda, third, José María Arteaga.  In fourht, almost in foreground, in front of lumber industry runs Mariano Matamoros Street.
On the post stamp-like (left lower corner is scratched 5/12/14 (May 12, 1914).  By then Villa was taking Paredón, Coahuila (about 35 miles west to Saltillo).   See El Paso Herald (The Library of Congress, Cronicling America), issue May 11, 1914:  "SALTILLO SIEGE IS INAUGRATED BY REBEL ARMY".  The city fell into rebels hands on May 21st, see The New York Times, issue May 23, 1914, besides the article, shows the ruins of Saltillo Casino, located in Benito Juárez and Hidalgo Streets (from this view, to the left of the cathedral).
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Plastic Surgeon
dr.robertoduarte@hotmail.com
